title: Cloudflare acquires Astro
summary:
Cloudflare has acquired The Astro Technology Company, the team behind the open-source Astro web framework. The core mission for Astroâ€”building the best framework for content-driven websitesâ€”will continue with increased resources and focus.

Key assurances for the Astro community are that the framework will remain free, open-source (MIT-licensed), and actively maintained. It will stay platform-agnostic, supporting all deployment targets, not just Cloudflare. The project's open governance and current roadmap also remain unchanged, with the entire team moving to Cloudflare.

The acquisition resolves Astro's previous struggle to build a sustainable business model around paid hosted services, which distracted from core framework development. The founders believe Cloudflare's infrastructure expertise complements Astro's framework approach, sharing a vision for the future of performant, content-centric web development.

With Cloudflare's backing, the team can now dedicate itself fully to advancing the framework, starting with the upcoming Astro 6 release and future roadmap.

title: 6-Day and IP Address Certificates Are Generally Available
summary:
Let's Encrypt has announced the general availability of two new certificate types: short-lived certificates and IP address certificates.

Short-lived certificates are valid for 160 hours (just over six days) and are designed to enhance security by drastically reducing the vulnerability window if a private key is compromised. They are an opt-in alternative to the standard certificates, requiring more frequent automated renewal. While Let's Encrypt plans to reduce its default certificate lifetime from 90 to 45 days in the coming years, short-lived certificates will remain an optional choice for subscribers with fully automated systems.

IP address certificates allow TLS authentication for servers using their IP addresses (both IPv4 and IPv6) instead of domain names. Due to the transient nature of IP addresses, these certificates are only issued with the short-lived 6-day validity period to ensure more frequent validation.

Both offerings aim to improve security by promoting automation and reducing reliance on less reliable certificate revocation mechanisms.

title: Michelangelo's first painting, created when he was 12 or 13
summary:
Michelangeloâ€™s earliest known painting, *The Torment of Saint Anthony*, was created when he was just 12 or 13 years old. The work, depicting the saint assailed by demons, was long not attributed to him. Its status changed after its 2008 sale, when cleaning and infrared analysis at the Metropolitan Museum of Art revealed a color palette and artistic corrections (*pentimenti*) consistent with Michelangeloâ€™s later style, as seen in the Sistine Chapel.

The Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, Texas, purchased the painting after finding no convincing evidence against Michelangeloâ€™s authorship, making it the only Michelangelo painting in the Americas and one of only four easel paintings attributed to him. Around a decade later, art historian Giorgio Bonsanti definitively confirmed the attribution. While some doubts remain, and Michelangelo himself may have considered it an immature work, the technical evidence strongly supports its creation by the young master.

title: Just the Browser
summary:
**Just the Browser** is an open-source project that helps users remove unwanted features from mainstream desktop web browsers (Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, and Firefox). It targets AI tools, telemetry, sponsored content, shopping integrations, default browser prompts, and other "annoyances" to deliver a cleaner, more private browsing experience.

The tool works by applying pre-configured group policy settingsâ€”hidden options intended for organizational IT managementâ€”without modifying the browser's core software. This means settings persist and browsers may display a "managed by your organization" message.

Setup is offered through automated installation scripts for Windows (PowerShell) and macOS/Linux (Terminal), with manual guides also provided. The project includes direct download links for each browser and detailed documentation explaining every disabled feature.

Key points include:
*   It currently supports Chrome, Edge, and Firefox on Windows and macOS, but **not** Linux versions or mobile devices.
*   Users can review, customize, or completely remove the applied settings.
*   It does not install ad-blockers (recommending uBlock Origin instead).
*   The approach aims to retain the security and compatibility benefits of mainstream browsers while stripping out unwanted bloat.

All resources and configuration files are available on GitHub.

title: Cursor's latest "browser experiment" implied success without evidence
summary:
Cursor's recent blog post, "Scaling long-running autonomous coding," describes an experiment where AI agents were tasked with building a web browser from scratch. The agents reportedly ran for a week, generating over one million lines of code. While the post frames this as a success in scaling autonomous development and shows a screenshot, it provides no evidence that the browser is functional.

Independent analysis of the linked GitHub repository reveals the code does not compile, with dozens of errors and warnings. Recent commits and automated builds consistently fail. The article argues the post creates an impression of a working prototype through suggestive language ("meaningful progress," "extremely difficult") but omits basic reproducibility markers like a working commit, build instructions, or a functional demo.

The author concludes that Cursor's extraordinary claim of agents making "real progress" on an ambitious project is not substantiated, as the experiment's output appears to be non-functional "AI slop" that cannot meet a minimal standard of compiling and rendering a basic webpage.

title: Lock-Picking Robot
summary:
This article introduces an open-source lock-picking robot designed as a security-conscious alternative to skeleton keys (like the TSA 007). The core problem is that universal keys create a major security flaw, but authorized personnel like locksmiths still need access. The robot addresses this by making unauthorized access more overt and time-consuming.

The device works by brute-forcing pin combinations. It feeds a thin wire through a custom, hollow key blank to mechanically test each possible pin height, taking about 0.7 seconds per combination. This method bypasses security pins but is exponentially slowed by more pins or cut depths (e.g., 35 minutes for a 5-pin lock vs. 3 minutes for a 4-pin lock). The goal is to make locks that are quick for this robot but very difficult and time-consuming for a human picker.

The project is fully open-source (GPL 3.0). It uses Dynamixel servo motors and an OpenRB driver board, with mechanical parts requiring FDM, SLA, and DMLS 3D printing for different components. A new metal key blank must be fabricated for each lock type.

Planned improvements include adding a better method to detect when the lock opens (like servo current feedback) and using that feedback to intelligently reduce the number of combinations needed. The article positions the robot as a fun tool for lock sport enthusiasts and a practical, more secure option for professionals.

title: Elasticsearch Was Never a Database
summary:
This article argues that Elasticsearch is fundamentally a search engine, not a database suitable for being a primary system of record for transactional (OLTP) workloads. While teams often start using it as a secondary search index, they can drift into making it their primary datastore, leading to significant problems.

The core issues stem from Elasticsearch's design priorities. It lacks true multi-document transactions, risking data inconsistency. Schema changes are difficult, often requiring full reindexes. Its query capabilities, while powerful for search and aggregations, are weak for relational operations like joins. Operational complexity is high, and its durability guarantees, while strong for individual documents, do not extend to coordinated, multi-step operations.

The author concludes that Elasticsearch excels as a dedicated search index but becomes a fragile and costly choice when forced to act as a primary database. The solution is to use a proper database (like Postgres) as the source of truth and keep Elasticsearch in its intended role, or to adopt a system like ParadeDB that integrates OLTP and search natively.

title: STFU
summary:
This article describes the creation of a web app called "STFU," designed to discourage people from playing loud audio in public spaces. The author was inspired by an annoying experience at an airport, where someone was watching videos at full volume. Lacking the confidence to confront the person directly, they instead built a simple application.

The app works by using a device's microphone to listen to ambient sound and then playing that same audio back with a roughly two-second delay. The author credits the AI assistant Claude for generating a working version of the code in a single prompt. While the exact psychological mechanism isn't detailed, the author suggests it creates an "auditory feedback loop" that causes enough cognitive dissonance to make the noisy individual stop.

The app was originally named "make-it-stop," but the author renamed it "STFU" after seeing a similar project by another developer, Tim Darcet, using that name. The tool is built with the Web Audio API and is presented as a public resource born from "spite," with the author encouraging others to use it freely.

title: Launch HN: Indy (YC S21) â€“ A support app designed for ADHD brains
summary:
**Summary:**

Indy is a mobile app designed specifically to help people with ADHD manage their daily tasks and responsibilities. It aims to address common ADHD challenges like task initiation, working memory lapses, and feeling overwhelmed by complex systems.

The core philosophy is to reduce friction and cognitive load. Instead of a traditional to-do list, Indy uses a simple, card-based interface for tasks. A key feature is the "Indy Button"â€”a large, prominent button that, when pressed, immediately presents the user with a small, manageable action to take next, helping to overcome paralysis at starting tasks.

The app emphasizes simplicity and gentle guidance over rigid productivity systems. It helps break projects into steps, surfaces the next action, and uses notifications and reminders tailored to ADHD needs (like less nagging, more supportive nudges). The goal is to build momentum with small wins and reduce the shame often associated with dropped tasks.

Founded in Y Combinator's S21 batch, Indy is available as a mobile app. It represents a shift towards creating digital tools with neurodiversity in mind, focusing on user experience and psychological support rather than just generic task management.

title: Read_once(), Write_once(), but Not for Rust
summary: The article discusses the Linux kernel's `READ_ONCE()` and `WRITE_ONCE()` macros, which ensure single, atomic access to memory for lockless algorithms. While a proposal was made to add Rust equivalents, Rust developers prefer using the `Atomic` crate's relaxed operations (`Atomic::from_ptr().load(Relaxed)`), arguing they provide clearer semantics and intent compared to the more ambiguous C macros. This decision means Rust and C code in the kernel will use different APIs for concurrent data access, potentially complicating development. The discussion also highlighted missing `READ_ONCE()` calls in existing C code, showing how Rust's presence can improve C code. Ultimately, the Rust community aims for more precise concurrency primitives, even if it leads to divergent implementations between languages.

title: Earth from Space: The Fate of a Giant
summary:
This European Space Agency article, based on a Copernicus Sentinel-2 satellite image from December 2025, details the final stages of the A23a iceberg.

A23a, which calved from Antarctica's Filchner-Ronne ice shelf in 1986, was once the world's largest iceberg at about 4,000 sq km. After being grounded for decades, it began drifting in 2020. By late 2023, it moved quickly northward, traveling roughly 2,000 km. It reached the warmer waters near South Georgia Island by May 2025, where its disintegration accelerated.

The image shows the iceberg approximately 150 km northwest of South Georgia, now reduced to about 1,000 sq kmâ€”a loss of three-quarters of its original areaâ€”though it remains one of the largest in open water. It is surrounded by smaller icebergs, and bright blue meltwater ponds on its surface are visible signs of its rapid breakup.

The article explains that this fate is typical for icebergs reaching these northern latitudes, caused by warmer sea temperatures and weather. As ocean currents push A23a into even warmer waters, it is expected to completely disintegrate soon, following the path of previous megabergs.

title: Dev-owned testing: Why it fails in practice and succeeds in theory
summary:
**Summary of "Dev-owned testing: Why it fails in practice and succeeds in theory"**

This article examines the concept of "dev-owned testing," where software developers are primarily responsible for creating and maintaining tests for their own code. The central argument is that while this model is theoretically soundâ€”promising faster feedback, better code quality, and increased developer ownershipâ€”it often fails in practice due to organizational and cultural constraints.

The authors identify a key contradiction: the theory assumes developers have the **time, skills, and motivation** to write high-quality tests. In reality, these conditions are frequently unmet. Development teams often face intense pressure to deliver features quickly, leading to testing being deprioritized. Furthermore, not all developers possess deep testing expertise, which can result in incomplete or ineffective test suites.

The paper highlights that successful dev-owned testing requires a significant **investment in developer enablement**. This includes dedicated training in testing techniques, allocating time for test creation within schedules, and fostering a quality-centric culture that values testing as a core engineering activity, not an afterthought. Without this foundational support, the responsibility simply shifts from dedicated testers to developers without providing them the necessary tools or incentives, leading to technical debt and quality issues.

In conclusion, the article posits that dev-owned testing is not inherently flawed, but its implementation often is. For it to succeed, organizations must move beyond mandating the practice and instead actively create the conditions that allow developers to be effective testers, bridging the gap between the ideal theory and practical reality.

title: Zep AI (Agent Context Engineering, YC W24) Is Hiring Forward Deployed Engineers
summary:
Zep AI, a Y Combinator W24 startup, is hiring for several roles, including Lead Forward Deployed Engineer. The company focuses on solving "agent context" problems by assembling relevant data from chat history and business systems to improve AI agent performance.

Key details from the post include:
*   **Open Positions:** Staff Engineer, Lead Forward Deployed Engineer, and Developer Relations Lead.
*   **Compensation:** Salaries range from $175K to $250K, plus equity (0.5% - 1.5%).
*   **Requirements:** Roles require 6+ years of experience and are open to remote work within the US.
*   **Company Profile:** Zep AI is a small, 5-person team based in San Francisco, founded in 2023. Its open-source project, Graphiti, gained significant traction with 20k GitHub stars. The platform offers fast, sub-200ms retrieval and is SOC 2/HIPAA certified.
*   **Employee Testimonials:** Current engineers highlight the technical leadership, opportunities for ownership, and the rewarding challenge of building products for the developer community.

The post positions Zep AI as a growing, technically rigorous startup where engineers can have significant impact.

title: The Alignment Game
summary:
This article describes "The Alignment Game," a process designed to help teams, particularly leadership groups, converge on a shared set of priorities. The author, an executive, observed that organizational growth often leads to fractured assumptions, where people agree on problems but disagree on their relative importance, causing misaligned efforts.

To address this, the author adopted stack ranking exercises. While fruitful with individuals, aligning a larger group required a more structured method. The solution leverages voting theory, specifically the **Kemeny-Young ranking algorithm**. This method finds the single priority order that minimizes total "disagreements" (where one person ranks A over B and another does the opposite) across all participants.

The author notes the Kemeny method's strength is its **interpretability**: it clearly shows which priorities are contentious and which team members are most misaligned, providing a concrete starting point for discussion. Its potential downside is that it can be a "compromise solution" that fully satisfies no one, so the output should be a conversation tool, not a rigid mandate.

The process involves individuals privately ranking priorities, aggregating the lists via the algorithm, and then using the revealed disagreements to guide focused debates. The author reports success using this method at company off-sites and has since automated it in a **Google Sheet** for others to use.

title: Why DuckDB is my first choice for data processing
summary:
DuckDB is an open-source, in-process SQL engine optimized for analytical workloads, making it the author's preferred tool for data processing, especially within Python. It stands out for its simplicity, speed, and rich feature set, positioning it as a strong alternative to complex cluster-based systems for most tabular data tasks.

Key advantages include its exceptional performance for joins and aggregations, often significantly faster than traditional OLTP databases. Installation is straightforward, with a single binary or a dependency-free Python package, facilitating rapid setup and ideal use in CI/CD pipelines and testing. The SQL dialect is user-friendly, introducing innovations like the `EXCLUDE` and `COLUMNS` keywords for more expressive queries.

DuckDB excels at directly querying various file formats (CSV, Parquet, JSON) from local disks or cloud storage. Its Python API allows for lazy evaluation of complex, multi-step queries, easing development and debugging. Additional standout features are full ACID compliance for data integrity, a streamlined system for high-performance C++ extensions, and excellent documentation.

The author concludes that DuckDB simplifies development and boosts performance, as evidenced by its successful adoption as the default backend in the Splink library, and highlights promising integrations with PostgreSQL as areas for future growth.

title: Show HN: 1Code â€“ Open-source Cursor-like UI for Claude Code
summary:
1Code is an open-source, Cursor-like user interface designed specifically for Claude Code, offering both local and remote agent execution capabilities. It features two main modes: Plan Mode for read-only code analysis and Agent Mode for full code execution permissions. The tool includes project management that links local folders with automatic Git remote detection, real-time visibility into bash commands, file edits, and web searches, and Git worktree isolation to keep each chat session separate. Additional functionalities are an integrated terminal and visual change tracking with PR management.

Users can install it for free by building from source using Bun, Python, and Xcode Command Line Tools (for macOS), or they can subscribe at 1code.dev to receive pre-built releases and background agent support, which helps fund ongoing development. The project is open-source under the Apache License 2.0, and the team encourages community feedback and discussion through their Discord server.

title: Feature Selection: A Primer
summary:
This article provides a statistical primer on filter-based feature selection methods, emphasizing their mathematical foundations. It begins by outlining the practical need for feature selectionâ€”such as simplifying models and reducing training timeâ€”and introduces the four levels of measurement (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio), which dictate the appropriate method to use.

The core of the article details two key filter methods. First, **Pearsonâ€™s r** measures the linear relationship between two continuous (interval/ratio) variables by standardizing their covariance. A coefficient near Â±1 indicates a strong linear association, while near 0 suggests a weak one.

Second, **Kendallâ€™s Ï„** assesses ordinal association by comparing the ranks of data points. It counts concordant pairs (ranks move together) and discordant pairs (ranks move oppositely), with Ï„ ranging from -1 (perfect negative association) to 1 (perfect positive association). Unlike Pearsonâ€™s r, Kendallâ€™s Ï„ can capture monotonic, non-linear relationships and handles ordinal data.

The article stresses that understanding the underlying statisticsâ€”like covariance, expectation, and levels of measurementâ€”is crucial for selecting the right method and building robust models. Code snippets are provided for practical implementation.

title: Emoji Use in the Electronic Health Record is Increasing
summary:
**Summary of "Emoji Use in the Electronic Health Record is Increasing"**

A study published in *JAMA Network Open* analyzed the use of emojis in the electronic health records (EHRs) of a large academic health system. The research found a significant and rapid increase in emoji usage within clinical notes between 2015 and 2022.

**Key Findings:**

*   **Rising Trend:** The proportion of patient notes containing at least one emoji rose from 0.4% in 2015 to 5.7% in 2022â€”a more than 14-fold increase.
*   **Common Emojis:** The most frequently used emojis were the "thumbs up" (ğŸ‘), "thumbs down" (ğŸ‘), and "check mark button" (âœ…). These are primarily used to convey simple, unambiguous information like treatment compliance ("thumbs up"), refusal ("thumbs down"), or completion ("check mark").
*   **Clinical Context:** Emojis were most commonly found in notes from outpatient specialties like rehabilitation, ophthalmology, and orthopedics. They were often used to document patient-reported status, such as pain levels or functional ability.
*   **Potential Benefits:** Researchers suggest emojis can serve as efficient, standardized visual cues that enhance the clarity and speed of communication among clinicians, potentially reducing documentation burden.
*   **Risks and Concerns:** The study highlights significant risks, including ambiguity (as emoji meaning can vary), lack of universal standards, and technical inconsistencies across different EHR platforms. There are also concerns about professionalism and the potential for miscommunication in serious medical contexts.

**Conclusion:** The study concludes that emoji use in EHRs is becoming more prevalent, driven by their utility for concise communication. However, it calls for the development of clinical guidelines and standards to govern their appropriate use, ensuring they improve rather than compromise patient care documentation.

title: OpenBSD-current now runs as guest under Apple Hypervisor
summary:
This article announces that OpenBSD-current can now run as a guest operating system on Apple Silicon Macs using the Apple Hypervisor framework. This breakthrough is the result of two key commits to the OpenBSD source code.

The first commit, by Helg Bredow, fixed a critical bug in the `viogpu.c` driver that was causing a kernel panic on the Apple Hypervisor. The fix ensures the framebuffer is correctly mapped and synchronized, enabling graphical output (like X11) to work properly.

The second commit, by Stefan Fritsch, added support for the VIRTIO network feature `VIRTIO_NET_F_MTU` in the `if_vio.c` driver. This allows OpenBSD to correctly negotiate the Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) with the hypervisor, which was a final blocker for full network functionality on Apple's virtualization platform.

These combined changes mean OpenBSD/arm64 now has the necessary graphics and networking support to function as a virtual machine guest on newer Apple Silicon hardware. The development is available in snapshots, and users with compatible Macs are encouraged to test it and provide feedback.

title: List of individual trees
summary:
This Wikipedia article lists notable individual trees from around the world, selected for their historical, cultural, natural, or mythological significance. It is organized geographically into sections for Africa, Asia, and Europe, with each region subdivided into "Living" and "Historical" trees.

The entries provide key details for each tree, including its common name, species, location, estimated age, and a brief note on its importance. Examples span from ancient natural wonders like the 4,500-year-old Cypress of Abarkuh in Iran and the clonal 9,567-year-old Old Tjikko spruce in Sweden, to culturally significant trees such as the Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi in Sri Lanka (a sacred fig linked to Buddha) and the Treaty Tree in South Africa. The list also includes trees famous for unique attributes, like the Sunland Baobab in South Africa, which housed a pub inside its hollow trunk, and historical specimens that have since been lost, such as the Tree of TÃ©nÃ©rÃ© in the Sahara.

Overall, the article serves as a catalog of remarkable trees, highlighting their roles as landmarks, religious symbols, historical witnesses, and record-holders for age or size.

title: Training my smartwatch to track intelligence
summary:
The author used personal data from a Garmin smartwatch and daily chess performance (ELO score changes) to build a predictive model for mental clarity. Using logistic regression, they achieved 60% accuracy in predicting daily wins/losses, better than the 50% chance baseline.

The analysis revealed surprising insights about which health metrics correlate with cognitive performance:
*   **REM sleep duration** was the strongest positive predictor.
*   **Garmin's "stress" metric** (inverse of HRV, indicating alertness) also positively correlated, aligning with the Yerkes-Dodson law on optimal arousal.
*   **Recent exercise** (active calories) had a short-term negative correlation, as fatigue can impair complex cognition.
*   **Deep sleep duration** showed no significant correlation with chess performance.

The author built a personal Garmin watch app to display a daily "mental clarity" score based on these metrics. Using it for months, they found it reliably predicted performance in cognitively demanding tasks, sometimes contradicting their own feelings or Garmin's reviews. This led to behavioral changes, like prioritizing REM sleep by reducing alcohol and using a weighted blanket. The app remains a personal tool due to Garmin's API restrictions.

title: Dell UltraSharp 52 Thunderbolt Hub Monitor
summary:
This article announces the new Dell UltraSharp 52 Thunderbolt Hub Monitor (model U5226KWSAP), priced at $2,899.99.

The key information is that this is a large-format 52-inch monitor that also functions as a Thunderbolt hub, suggesting it can connect and charge multiple devices like laptops through a single cable. The listing highlights available financing options for the premium price.

Product identification details are provided: the manufacturer part number (15DKC), Dell part number (210-BTHW), and the specific order code (u5226kwsap). The "Compare" feature indicates the product can be evaluated against other models on Dell's website.

In summary, the core announcement is for a high-end, large-screen monitor with integrated Thunderbolt hub functionality, offered at a premium price point with financing available.

title: psc: The ps utility, with an eBPF twist and container context
summary:
**Summary of psc**

psc is a next-generation process scanner that uses eBPF (extended Berkeley Packet Filter) to provide secure, kernel-level visibility into system processes, containers, and their network connections. Unlike traditional tools like `ps` that read from the manipulable `/proc` filesystem, psc uses eBPF iterators to query kernel data structures directly, making it resistant to userland rootkits and `LD_PRELOAD` attacks.

Its key innovation is the integration of Google's Common Expression Language (CEL), which replaces cumbersome command-line pipelines with a single, precise filtering expression. Users can query processes based on name, user, PID, command line, container context (runtime, name, image), and open file descriptors or sockets (type, state, port).

psc excels at container debugging from the host, allowing operators to inspect a container's process tree, network connections, and open files without entering it. It offers flexible output formatting with custom columns and tree views.

Built for Linux kernels 5.8+, it requires root privileges to load its eBPF programs. The tool is designed for security and operational tasks, such as detecting hidden processes, investigating suspicious network activity, and auditing containerized environments with greater accuracy and efficiency than traditional utilities.

title: Zorgdomein Integration: A Guide to Secure .NET and Azure Architecture
summary:
This article details the technical challenges and solutions for integrating a proprietary healthcare SaaS platform with Zorgdomein, the central Dutch healthcare communication gateway. It emphasizes that such interoperability is a high-stakes architectural challenge requiring a focus on security, compliance, and data integrity.

The core technical hurdles involved a "Double-Lock" security model: first, configuring **Mutual TLS (mTLS)** in IIS for certificate-based transport security, and second, implementing **custom JWT authentication middleware** to handle Zorgdomein's specialized tokens for application-level identity and authorization.

A major architectural component was the **data transformation layer**. The project required mapping internal .NET POCOs to standardized **FHIR resources**, specifically adhering to Dutch HL7 profiles. This involved building a dedicated, bidirectional mapping service using the Hl7.Fhir.Net library to ensure semantic correctness and validation in both directions.

The key takeaway is that healthcare interoperability must be treated as a core architectural discipline, not a secondary task. Success depends on meticulously engineering the secure handshake, robust identity verification, and standardized data exchange to build a scalable and compliant platform.

title: How to wrangle non-deterministic AI outputs into conventional software? (2025)
summary:
This article addresses the challenge of integrating non-deterministic AI outputs, like those from LLMs, into deterministic software systems. It uses the example of classifying the business domains addressed in a codebase to illustrate the problem: while an LLM can generate sensible domain categories for a code sample, the categories vary each time, making aggregation and comparison across files impossible.

The author distinguishes between **modeling** (creating a categorization scheme) and **classification** (assigning items to categories). To achieve consistency, he recommends separating these tasks: first, establish a **canonical, frozen set of categories** (the model), and then use that fixed list to classify individual code modules.

The article explores several techniques for creating this model, including incremental updates and iterative refinement with critic/judge models. However, it advocates for a simpler, often superior solution: **using an established standard model** like NAICS (a published industry classification). A standard model provides a stable, low-ambiguity taxonomy that leads to more consistent LLM classification, reduces modeling effort, and aligns with Domain-Driven Design's "Published Language" pattern. The key takeaway is to treat the categorization scheme as a generic subdomain and use a standard model when possible, reserving custom modelingâ€”whether AI-assisted or human-drivenâ€”for truly core domain differentiators.

title: Reading across books with Claude Code
summary:
This article describes a project that uses Claude Code, an AI agent, to analyze a library of 100 non-fiction books and generate "trails"â€”sequences of excerpts connected by a common theme, like deception in business. Instead of just summarizing, the system helps users read deeper by discovering unexpected connections across texts.

The process involves splitting books into chunks, extracting topics with an LLM, and indexing them in a searchable hierarchy. Claude Code navigates this index using custom CLI tools to find novel connections, piece together excerpts, and craft coherent trails.

Key insights from the project include:
1.  **Agents excel at complex tasks:** Using Claude as an active agent was more effective than a rigid, multi-stage pipeline, allowing for flexible exploration and revision.
2.  **Tool design is crucial:** The focus shifted from optimizing prompts to building better tools for the agent, treating it like a coworker with predictable needs.
3.  **Novelty guides discovery:** The system prioritizes under-explored topics and books to find fresh, interesting connections, though it sometimes veers toward conspiratorial themes.

The technical implementation uses SQLite for storage, embeddings for topic similarity, and graph clustering to organize topics into a browsable tree, processing the entire corpus for about Â£10.

title: Interactive eBPF
summary:
This article introduces an interactive, browser-based platform for learning eBPF (extended Berkeley Packet Filter) through hands-on exercises. It outlines a structured curriculum divided into three chapters, guiding users from foundational concepts to more advanced applications.

The learning path begins with an introduction and platform overview, then moves to concept familiarization. This first chapter covers process context, reading event data, tracing system calls, and handling syscall arrays.

Chapter 2 focuses on stateful eBPF programming, teaching users how to use maps to store data across multiple program runs, read syscall buffers, track state between different system calls, and monitor network connections.

The final chapter introduces kernel probes, a more advanced technique for attaching eBPF programs to internal kernel functions, with a practical exercise on reading TCP packet data.

The platform emphasizes a practical, code-first approach where users can write, compile, and run eBPF programs directly in their browser. The article concludes by inviting community contribution, encouraging users to report issues or suggest new exercises, and provides a link for those curious about the platform's underlying technology.

title: Our approach to advertising and expanding access to ChatGPT
summary:
Based on the article from OpenAI's official website, here is a concise summary:

OpenAI is introducing a new approach to expand access to ChatGPT by exploring **advertising**. The primary goal is to keep their flagship AI tool free for millions of users worldwide while developing sustainable revenue streams to support ongoing research and development.

The key points are:
*   **Free Access Remains:** OpenAI is committed to continuing free access to ChatGPT. Advertising is seen as a way to support this model, not replace it.
*   **Exploring Ads:** They are in the early stages of exploring how to integrate ads, with a focus on ensuring they are **relevant, unobtrusive, and respect user privacy**. The intent is to create a non-intrusive experience.
*   **User Privacy First:** Any advertising will be built with a strong commitment to user privacy. OpenAI states they will not use personal conversations with ChatGPT for ad targeting.
*   **Expanding Reach:** This initiative is part of a broader effort to make advanced AI tools available to as many people as possible, ensuring that the benefits of AI are widely distributed.

In essence, OpenAI is testing advertising as a supplementary method to fund the free version of ChatGPT, emphasizing that user experience and privacy will be central to any implementation.

title: Can You Disable Spotlight and Siri in macOS Tahoe?
summary:
This article explains how to minimize the operation of Siri and Spotlight in macOS, noting that they cannot be completely removed without disabling System Integrity Protection (SIP).

For **Siri**, the only user-accessible method is to disable "Siri Requests" in System Settings. While this deactivates its core functions, related background processes (like `siriactionsd`) will still run at startup and appear in Activity Monitor.

For **Spotlight**, simply unchecking all categories in System Settings does not stop it. The article evaluates two Terminal commands:
*   `sudo mdutil -a -i off` disables indexing but **does not** stop searches, and its effectiveness on the Data volume may be inconsistent.
*   `sudo mdutil -a -d` is the recommended command, as it disables **both indexing and searching** on all volumes, reducing Spotlight to a state where searches return no results.

Even after using the `-d` flag, Spotlight-related processes (like `mds`) remain active, and hidden `.Spotlight-V100` folders persist on volumes (though they stay empty). Spotlight can be re-enabled with `sudo mdutil -a -i on`.

In summary, to minimize both features:
1.  Turn off Siri Requests in System Settings.
2.  Run `sudo mdutil -a -d` in Terminal.

title: Slop Is Everywhere for Those with Eyes to See
summary:
This article argues that social media platforms like TikTok and Meta are designed to maximize user consumption through features like the infinite-scrolling "For You Page" (FYP), which hides time and creates an illusion of endless content. This relentless demand for content has led to an oversupply of low-quality, AI-generated material ("slop"), as human creativity cannot scale to meet the platforms' needs.

The author explains that platforms face a fundamental problem: only 1-3% of users create content (the 90-9-1 rule). While platforms can optimize tools, they cannot manufacture creative spark. This makes creators a volatile variable, as demonstrated by the 2016 "Vine 20" incident, where top creators collectively left, causing the app's demise. Modern algorithms now tightly control virality to prevent such collective power.

This system harms both consumers and creators. For users, effortless algorithmic curation flattens curiosity and devalues information. For creators, the pressure to feed the content machine cheapens their work. The article concludes by advocating a return to the "open web"â€”actively seeking out art and writing on independent sitesâ€”as an act of mindful consumption, reclaiming control from platforms designed solely for engagement.
